content: The chef Sandro Fioriti has owned a restaurant bearing his name in New York since 1985. Now, at 74, he’s still tossing pasta, in a new location. He opened his first with the help of Tony May at 420 East 59th Street, previously occupied by the super-luxe Palace. (It is now Pino Luongo’s Morso.) Then, in 2006, after a few interim gigs, he opened his spot on the Upper East Side, at 306 East 81st Street. That restaurant closed in February, and he has relocated to East 86th Street, in the former Little Frog. Throughout he was noted for his cuisine, inspired by his native Umbria and Rome, where he trained, long before Roman food achieved its current prominence in New York. He is now joined by his son, Sandro Fioriti Jr., who runs the restaurant, with his father in the kitchen turning out his well-regarded spaghetti al limone, rigatoni amatriciana, cacio e pepe, fried artichokes and pollo cacciatora alla romana. The younger Mr. Fioriti, who has been involved for the past eight years, said that the menu was essentially the same as it was on 81st Street, and that the kitchen and dining room staff also made the move. There are 56 seats in a somewhat formal room with a big bar, white napery and white brick walls.

content: For the past six years, Donald J. Trump’s most loyal supporters have gone on the attack against federal law-enforcement officials whenever they have sought to investigate the former president or his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Rodgers and Jesse Green
title: The Princess and the Poconos
description: In this excerpt from “Shy: The Alarmingly Outspoken Memoirs of Mary Rodgers,” a Broadway musical is born at a summer camp.
content: A hundred-mile drive from New York City, on the fringe of the Pocono Mountains, Tamiment was for much of the last midcentury a resort for singles and a summer intensive for emerging theatrical talent. During the first half of each season, writers assembled an original musical revue every week; in the second half, if they were interested in cranking out a show with a story — and if Moe Hack, the barky, crusty, cigar-smoking sweetheart who ran the place, thought it was a good idea — they would be free to try.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Dekneef and Mariko Reed
title: A Painter’s Home That Celebrates Hawaii
description: The Honolulu home of Jean Charlot, a French expatriate artist, embodies his appreciation for the surrounding landscape.
content: WHEN THE FRENCH American muralist Jean Charlot arrived in postwar Hawaii in 1949 on a commission to paint a fresco in the foyer of a newly built administration building at the University of Hawaii at Manoa in Honolulu, he had no intention of making the islands his home. The 51-year-old artist’s goal was to complete a lush 10-by-29-foot depiction of ancient Hawaiian life, replete with poi pounding, spearfishing and seated hula dancing, set during the inauspicious moment right before Captain Cook’s approaching Resolution was sighted offshore by the natives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A quick history of Mar-a-Lago, Trump’s lavish club and residence.
description: The property’s roots go back to a very different wealthy American: It was built in the 1920s by Marjorie Merriweather Post, heiress and then owner of General Foods.
content: Mar-a-Lago, the opulent 20-acre private club and residence at the center of Palm Beach, Fla., was purchased by Donald J. Trump in 1985. It eventually became a symbol of his brand and a central location for his presidency, as a backdrop for meetings with Republican allies and foreign leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Russia says oil flows to three European Union members have been halted.
description: A state-owned operator of a Russian pipeline to Europe said its payment to the Ukrainian operator of the pipeline had been returned, blaming issues linked to European sanctions against Russia.
content: In another sign of the fragility of Europe’s supply, flows of oil from Russia to Central Europe have halted over a pipeline payments dispute, raising fears that an “energy war” between Moscow and its European oil customers could escalate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: The Long, Long Wait for a Diabetes Cure
description: A documentary captures the desperation and frustration of Type 1 diabetes patients in a clinical trial.
content: In the three decades since she was first diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes, Lisa Hepner has clung to a vague promise she often heard from doctors convinced medical science was on the cusp of making her body whole again. “Stay strong,” they would say. “A cure is just five years away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The House Jan. 6 panel is scheduled to interview Pompeo and Mastriano on Tuesday.
description: Douglas V. Mastriano, a point person in Pennsylvania for a plan to fake electors to keep Donald J. Trump in power, plans to object to the panel’s rules about video recording.
content: In the wake of the F.B.I. search of former President Donald J. Trump’s property in Florida, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is gearing up to meet with two potentially key witnesses in its separate inquiry on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Signs Industrial Policy Bill Aimed at Bolstering Competition With China
description: The legislation invests in American chip manufacturing and is part of a streak of legislative successes that President Biden is planning to highlight as the midterm elections approach.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday signed into law a sprawling $280 billion bill aimed at bolstering American chip manufacturing to address global supply chain issues and counter the rising influence of China, part of a renewed effort by the White House to galvanize its base around a recent slate of legislative victories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Jesus Jiménez
title: ‘Hamilton’ Team Protests After Church Production Adds Christian Themes
description: A church in Texas changed several lyrics in its unauthorized staging of the megahit musical, softening language and inserting religious messages.
content: Lawyers for the creators of “Hamilton,” the record-setting musical that remains a worldwide draw seven years after its Broadway debut, protested after a Texas church put on an unauthorized production this weekend. Church performers changed some lyrics and introduced Christian themes that were not part of the original.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The F.B.I. search is separate from the Justice Department’s Jan. 6 investigation.
description: One inquiry appears to focus on materials taken from the White House at the end of the Trump presidency; the other is centered on a plan to create slates of false electors to change the outcome of the 2020 election.
content: The F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s home on Monday to obtain information related to his handling of classified information is separate from the Justice Department’s investigation into the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021, according to multiple people familiar with the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: With Deal in Hand, Democrats Enter the Fall Armed With Something New: Hope
description: Democrats say the climate and tax bill will help win over a skeptical electorate in November, as Republicans try to galvanize their base against a progressive wish list.
content: Vulnerable incumbent Democratic senators like Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire are holding events promoting the landmark legislation they passed over the weekend. Democratic ad makers are busily preparing a barrage of commercials about it across key battlegrounds. And the White House is set to deploy Cabinet members on a nationwide sales pitch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Judith Durham, Singer of ‘Georgy Girl’ and Other Hits, Dies at 79
description: A classically trained soprano, she became a chart-topping pop star in the 1960s with the folk-based Australian quartet the Seekers.
content: Judith Durham, the lead vocalist of the 1960s Australian folk-pop band the Seekers, whose shimmering soprano voice and wholesome image propelled singles like “Georgy Girl” and “I’ll Never Find Another You” to the top of the pop charts, died on Friday in Melbourne. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: When can we expect primary election results in Wisconsin and elsewhere?
description: While it is hard to predict when we might get returns on election night, there are factors that can give us clues.
content: Most of the attention on Tuesday will be focused on Wisconsin, a battleground state where Republican voters are deciding who will challenge Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, in a primary that has become another proxy battle between former President Donald J. Trump and his former vice president, Mike Pence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: I Get Up and Nothin' Gets Me Down
description: Bruce Haight offers a puzzling twist on a classic tale.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Hello, Wordplay! I hope you are all ready to get up and let nothin’ get you down as we tackle Bruce Haight’s artistic Tuesday puzzle (his 60th New York Times Crossword!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: William Ruto, the self-proclaimed champion of Kenya’s ‘hustler nation’
description: The candidate’s electoral pitch focuses on hard-working and ambitious young people.
content: William Ruto loves to tell of his humble origins — his barefoot childhood in the Rift Valley; his first pair of shoes at age 15; the time he scraped by selling chickens and ground nuts on the side of a busy highway.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Couple With Nothing to Talk About’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: One recent summer evening, my husband and I were sitting by the fire pit at our home north of Chicago, watching the flames dance, feeling tired but content. If someone had been watching us, they may have thought, “Now there’s a couple with nothing to talk about.” But, after 38 years of marriage — and a day biking and working in the backyard — I thought, “Who else could I do this with? Who else would I want to do this with?” Hours later, we checked the embers, covered the pit and headed wordlessly up to bed. — Ellen Blum Barish
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: What is a federal search warrant?
description: Federal law enforcement officials’ use of a warrant does not indicate guilt, but it does indicate a sense of prosecutorial urgency.
content: Federal law enforcement officials obtain search warrants when they need to move quickly on a criminal investigation, or are concerned that sensitive materials they need might be in danger of being moved, concealed, altered or destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greta Rybus
title: For an Article on ‘Ice Mermaids,’ Taking the (Very Cold) Plunge
description: To document the practice of cold-water plunging in the near-freezing waters of Maine, a photojournalist took to the ice, then under it.
content: Being a photojournalist means perpetually job shadowing; being a forever beginner; and a regular visitor. Each day, we learn how to navigate the world from the people willing to invite us into theirs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews William MacAskill
description: A covnersation with philosopher William MacAskill.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with William MacAskill. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Brodribb and Shibon Kennedy
title: This Fall, Outerwear Will Be Furry, Fluffy and Wild
description: With an array of textures, these styles bring a spirit of adventure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Ilhan Omar faces a primary challenge in her Minnesota House district.
description: Four opponents, including the former Minneapolis city councilman Don Samuels, are competing to unseat the incumbent.
content: Representative Ilhan Omar, one of Congress’s most prominent lawmakers, is facing four Democratic primary challengers in Minnesota as she seeks her third term, making her the latest member of the progressive group known as the “squad” to defend her seat this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Connecticut: Here’s how to vote, where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
description: Here is a refresher on the rules for voting and what’s at stake in Connecticut on Tuesday.
content: Connecticut might be known as a campaign fund-raising powerhouse that rarely deviates from electing Democrats statewide, but even its primary on Tuesday is drawing the attention of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: From the archives: A look at the inquiry that led to the F.B.I. search of Trump’s Florida home.
description: The National Archives discovered in January that at the end of his term, former President Donald J. Trump had taken to his home at the Mar-a-Lago resort 15 boxes from the White House that contained government documents, mementos, gifts and letters. The boxes included material subject to the Presidential Records Act, which requires that all documents and records pertaining to official business be turned over to the archives.
content: The National Archives discovered in January that at the end of his term, former President Donald J. Trump had taken to his home at the Mar-a-Lago resort 15 boxes from the White House that contained government documents, mementos, gifts and letters. The boxes included material subject to the Presidential Records Act, which requires that all documents and records pertaining to official business be turned over to the archives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Taunts Trump for Bad Bathroom Behavior
description: “To be fair, it’s unclear if those are official White House documents or his toilet’s suicide note,” Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Fisher and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Mexico City Declared Police Abuse Over. Reports of Misconduct Kept Rising.
description: The police and city officials have turned a blind eye to misconduct, current and former police officials say — leaving victims of abuse, many of them poor, with little recourse.
content: MEXICO CITY — Juan Carlos García Cortés was running errands in Mexico City on his moped when a taxi cut him off and two men jumped out. They shoved him in the back, threw a jacket over his head and began beating him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and David Enrich
title: Federal Authorities Investigate Firm Linked to Roman Abramovich
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the F.B.I. have been investigating Concord Management, people close to the firm said.
content: Federal authorities are investigating Concord Management, a small investment advisory firm that oversaw billions of dollars in hedge fund investments for the Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, according to people close to the firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy
title: A View From China on How Perceptions of America Have Changed
description: A member of the Communist Party talks about how his country used to admire the United States.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 9, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 9, 2022.
content: An article on Sunday about safety fears over fighting around a nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine misspelled the name of the Ukrainian state nuclear company. It is Energoatom, not Enerhoatam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The Information Battleground
description: Russia takes over cyberspace in occupied Ukraine.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The F.B.I. search ignited the language of violence and civil war on the far right.
description: Pro-Trump influencers, figures in the media and even some Republican candidates for office employed the language to rally opposition.
content: For the past six years, Donald J. Trump’s most loyal backers have, as though by reflex, attacked federal law-enforcement officials whenever they have sought to investigate the former president or his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: If Trump illegally removed official records, would he be barred from future office?
description: The F.B.I.’s search of the former president’s Florida residence has drawn attention to a crime whose penalties include disqualification from future office — and the prospect of a fight over its constitutionality.
content: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. search of former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Florida has raised the question of whether the criminal investigation could lead to legally blocking him from becoming president again, even if he decides to run in the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Why China’s Confidence Could Turn Out to Be a Weakness
description: State propaganda about China’s rise is stoking extreme nationalism. That could blind China to its problems, and could lead to conflict — perhaps over Taiwan.
content: In his decade of ruling China, Xi Jinping has tried to imbue its people with confidence, telling them that the country is doing very well compared with the chaotic West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Song
title: Admiring the Trees of Paris
description: From the dramatic weeping willows along the Seine to the London plane trees that line the Champs-Élysées, trees play a supporting role in the city’s inimitable elegance and grandeur.
content: As a Paris resident, I scarcely paid attention to the city’s tree-scape until a few years ago, when I stumbled upon an arresting scene of a young man stretched out in the elbow of a low-lying branch of a Japanese pagoda tree, its leaves skimming the pond at Buttes-Chaumont Park in the 19th arrondissement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Scutts
title: More Than a Muse
description: Mark Braude’s biography of a bohemian icon makes a case for Kiki de Montparnasse as an artist in her own right.
content: We open just as Kiki de Montparnasse begins to sing. It’s a scene narrated in the present tense, stitched together from a patchwork of memories — for who didn’t leave a record of their time in 1920s Paris? Especially if they’d managed to elbow their way into the Jockey, with its sticky floors, graffitied walls and stiff cocktails, where Kiki — queen of the neighborhood — purred her nostalgic songs. If you could smell it, said one contemporary, her voice would be “garlic hitting a pan’s hot butter and wine”: pungent, irresistible and impossible to recapture once it’s gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The F.B.I. Searches Donald Trump’s Home
description: Also, a deadly flood in Seoul and a tense presidential election in Kenya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Raises Prices of F-150 Lightning Electric Truck, Citing Rising Material Costs
description: Demand for electric vehicles has been far stronger than the supply of battery materials like lithium, nickel and cobalt.
content: Ford Motor on Tuesday became the latest automaker to raise the price of electric vehicles when it significantly increased prices of its popular F-150 Lightning because of rising materials costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben McGrath
title: From Pittsburgh to New Orleans, on a 19th-Century-Style Flatboat
description: In “Life on the Mississippi,” Rinker Buck takes a lengthy river trip to examine a uniquely American history.
content: A dry cleaner in Yankton, S.D., once told me that he had spied so many fussily costumed boaters from the banks of the nearby Missouri River that he’d grown weary of new arrivals. “People are recreating Lewis and Clark,” he said. “It happens here all the time.” He loved the river, for its waterfowl and promise of imaginative escape, but not always its thru-traveling flock, who, if not reprising the migration of previous generations, often seemed to be proselytizing for one thing or another: energy independence, say, or sobriety. “Some of these people are a little on their high horse, you know?” he said. To meet a waterborne voyager whose only cause was wanderlust: That was novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Lee
title: The Cruelty Is Coming From Inside the House
description: Two eerie story collections depict the mundanity of human suffering.
content: Virgil, Emily Dickinson, Franz Kafka: It has become something of a cliché, authors on their deathbeds requesting that their unpublished works be destroyed (requests that literary executors have a fortunate habit of betraying). But the prolific 20th-century French writer Barbara Molinard was unwilling to take any such chances, tearing her short stories to shreds as soon as she wrote them. The malevolent and disorienting tales in her 1969 collection, “Panics,” represent her only surviving work. Saved from destruction by Molinard’s friend Marguerite Duras, who estimated that these 14 stories represent “maybe a hundredth” of what Molinard wrote, they have been translated for the first time into English, by Emma Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Louie and Elizabeth Paton
title: Issey Miyake, Who Opened a Door for Japanese Fashion, Dies at 84
description: The first Japanese designer to show in Paris, he was known for his origami-like designs, creating pleated skirts, dresses and trousers that afforded freedom.
content: Issey Miyake, one of the first Japanese designers to show in Paris, whose pleated style of clothing allowed for freedom of movement and whose name became a global byword for cutting-edge fashion in the 1980s, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gavin Edwards
title: Lamont Dozier, Writer of Numerous Motown Hits, Dies at 81
description: With the brothers Brian and Eddie Holland, Mr. Dozier wrote dozens of singles that reached the pop or R&B charts, including “You Can’t Hurry Love,” by the Supremes.
content: Lamont Dozier, the prolific songwriter and producer who was crucial to the success of Motown Records as one-third of the Holland-Dozier-Holland team, died on Monday at his home near Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Chase Mishkin, Tony-Winning Producer of ‘Dame Edna,’ Dies at 85
description: She was nearly 60 when she began producing shows on Broadway. In 19 years, she had a hand (and her money) in 30 plays and musicals.
content: Chase Mishkin, a prolific theatrical producer who received two Tony Awards, one for bringing the uninhibited Australian character Dame Edna Everage to Broadway, and who was something of flamboyant figure herself, chauffeured around town in her London taxicab, died on July 24 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: U.S. Moves to Stretch Out Monkeypox Vaccine Supply
description: The approach, which would require a new emergency authorization, would involve injecting one-fifth of the current dose into the skin instead of a full dose into underlying fat.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has decided to stretch out its limited supply of monkeypox vaccine by allowing a different method of injection that uses one-fifth as much per shot, according to people familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Voting Is Over in Kenya’s Election. Now the Battle Continues.
description: The two front-runners for the presidency — one making his fifth attempt — said victory was within reach. But a dispute over the results seems inevitable, and the next phase could be turbulent.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A wave of relief tinged with jubilation washed across Kenya on Tuesday as its hotly contested presidential election passed largely peacefully after months of bitter jostling and mud slinging. Supporters feted one of the front-runners, Raila Odinga, at his Nairobi stronghold, while his rival, William Ruto, praised the majesty of democracy after casting his ballot before dawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francisco Goldman
title: Guatemala’s Corrupt Officials Train Their Sights on the Press
description: The arrest of José Rubén Zamora, an award-winning journalist and president of the elPeriódico newspaper, marks an escalation of the government’s assault on democratic values.
content: MEXICO CITY — When I last saw José Rubén Zamora, the owner and director of Guatemala’s leading investigative newspaper, elPeriódico, in early June, he told me he suspected that the government was cooking up a case against him. His fears were not unfounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. and Iran Weighing ‘Final’ E.U. Offer on Nuclear Deal
description: Tehran has dropped a key demand that stalled the talks for months, but it now has a new one.
content: Seventeen months after the United States and Iran began negotiating a possible return to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal abandoned by President Donald J. Trump, the European Union has presented a “final” proposal for the two sides to consider before the talks collapse for good, Western officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Republican officials reacted with fury to news of the search.
description: One Florida lawmaker suggested amending state laws regarding federal agencies.
content: Top Republicans and prominent conservatives reacted with outrage on Monday night to the news that the F.B.I. had searched the private residence of former President Donald J. Trump, with some suggesting that federal agents should be arrested and others hinting that the court-approved law-enforcement action against Mr. Trump was pushing the country toward political chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Matt Carpenter’s Dream Season for Yankees Is in Jeopardy
description: The resurgent Carpenter fractured his left foot on a foul tip. No timetable has been given for his return.
content: If Matt Carpenter’s season is over after he fractured his foot on Monday in Seattle, he at least joined some elite company. His shocking resurgence at age 36 has put his name alongside some of the best hitters in franchise history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Overlooked Provisions
description: Climate has received most of the attention. But the Senate bill brings big changes to health care, too.
content: The climate provisions in the bill that the Senate passed this weekend are likely to be more consequential than anything else in the bill. They will lead to a sharp reduction in U.S. greenhouse gas emissions, experts say, and help address arguably the world’s most pressing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Searching for Signs of Lyon at Daniel Boulud’s Le Gratin
description: The chef’s latest restaurant is billed as a “bouchon Lyonnais.” So where are the intestine sausages?
content: Right up until the moment he actually opened one, nobody appeared more qualified to run a Lyon-style bouchon in New York City than Daniel Boulud. Then along came Le Gratin, and it became clear that he wasn’t the right person for the job at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: The investigation into Trump’s handling of classified material is just one of several inquiries he is facing.
description: Authorities in New York and Georgia are pursuing investigations, as are the Justice Department and the House Jan. 6 committee.
content: The F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida on Monday was a stunning step by the Justice Department in its apparent investigation into materials that were improperly taken by the former president, including classified documents, when he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: For Serena Williams, Tennis — Not Motherhood — Was a Sacrifice
description: Williams was bedridden for six weeks after childbirth because of life-threatening blood clots. She was playing in a Wimbledon final less than a year later.
content: When given the opportunity to write an essay in the September issue of Vogue, one that would touch on how she expects to “evolve” away from tennis, Serena Williams started by talking about her daughter, Alexis Olympia Ohanian Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: A Big TV Hit Is a Conservative Fantasy Liberals Should Watch
description: America is as divided over its favorite prestige television shows as news sources.
content: We may vote once a year, but most of us watch television every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: By Train, Bus or Uber, Giuliani Is Told to Come to Georgia
description: A judge in Atlanta tentatively ordered Rudolph W. Giuliani to appear before a special grand jury investigating meddling in the 2020 election.
content: ATLANTA — Rudolph W. Giuliani, the lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump and a central figure in the investigation into election interference in Georgia, has been telling prosecutors that he cannot travel to the state to appear before a special grand jury because he is not healthy enough to fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Olivia Newton-John: That Headband Was a Crown
description: When the singer smudged her classy image, she “unlocked something new that shot her to the top of pop’s Olympus,” our critic writes: “The vestal vamp.”
content: We would’ve just called her ONJ now. But part of the appeal, I think, was all of that name, the possible royalty of it. Nobody wanted to waste a syllable. Olivia Newton-John. Just saying it might bestow a crown. The rest of her allure sprang from that classiness: She was neither queen nor first lady of anything, yet she seemed, ultimately, like … a lady. And that was something she could have some fun with, a category she could smudge. Eventually. I mean, this was a person who, at the heights of funk, disco and glam rock, recorded six country-esque albums, throw pillows for your ears. And most of their singles topped what was once known as Billboard’s easy listening chart. (So maybe she was the queen of that.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maddy Crowell
title: She’s at Brown. Her Heart’s Still in Kabul.
description: In their first year at U.S. universities, women who escaped the Taliban are struggling to adjust — and to reckon with what they left behind.
content: It was late February when Suhaila Hashimi slid into one of the last available seats in the front row of her philosophy class, “The Place of Persons,” an intro-level course at Brown University about the moral and metaphysical status of personhood. Even though she was 23, and this was a class mostly for students who were several years younger, Hashimi fit in with them, her dark brown hair pulled into a messy ponytail, eyeliner darkening her lower lids, an oversize hoodie with Brown’s emblem on the front, black jeans tucked into black combat boots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Isabella Simonetti
title: The Fed Is Cooling Down the Economy, but Stocks Are Hot. What Gives?
description: Investors are pinning their hopes on a rosy outcome for inflation and growth, driving the S&P 500 up 12 percent in the past two months.
content: Stocks have roared back from their low in June, as investors bet that inflation has peaked, even as the Federal Reserve signals that its campaign to cool the economy by raising interest rates isn’t over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: When and Where to Watch Serena Williams Play Before She Retires
description: Williams was vague about the exact timing of her retirement, but she did say that she plans to attempt another run at the U.S. Open, which starts later this month.
content: Those interested in watching Serena Williams on her road to retirement will have opportunities to do so in at least three tournaments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Was There a Biden Boom?
description: And if so, why aren’t people feeling it?
content: Two weeks ago, I wrote a newsletter that I foolishly considered somewhat anodyne, not likely to get much reaction. It seemed probable that the initial estimate for G.D.P. growth in the second quarter would be negative and that many people would declare that this meant the United States was in a recession. So I spent some time pedantically explaining why we don’t actually use “two negative quarters” to define recessions and why, given other data, America probably wasn’t in one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden signs measures giving U.S. approval to Sweden and Finland’s bids to join NATO.
description: The expansion of NATO has received overwhelming support among Democrats and Republicans in a deeply divided Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed measures on Tuesday approving the expansion of NATO to include Sweden and Finland, an effort to bolster the Western alliance after President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: A Music Career Is a Risky Bet. In ‘Mija,’ the Stakes Are Even Higher.
description: A new documentary follows Doris Anahi Muñoz, the daughter of undocumented Mexican immigrants, as she balances the needs of her family with artistic dreams.
content: As a middle schooler with big dreams living in San Bernardino, Calif., Doris Anahi Muñoz made her bedroom walls a canvas. She painted her hands on the back of her door, with the words, “These are the hands of Doris Anahi Muñoz, and they’re going to touch the hearts of millions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. Is Urgently Seeking a Country to Resettle a Qaeda Informant
description: Government lawyers said the transfer of Majid Khan was a high priority because he pleaded guilty to war crimes and his sentence at Guantánamo Bay had ended.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — U.S. diplomats have asked 11 countries if they would be willing to take in a former courier for Al Qaeda who was tortured by the C.I.A. and became a government informant, Justice Department lawyers said in a court filing on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: What Is Heat Rash and How Do You Treat It?
description: This itchy, bumpy condition is often confused for other ailments, but it’s always an indication that you should get out of the sun.
content: With many parts of the country experiencing dangerous levels of heat, some may have noticed itchy, red bumps cropping up on certain parts of the body. Excessive heat and humidity can make you more prone to heat rash, a common condition that develops on the neck, shoulders, chest and folds of the skin. But what is heat rash, exactly, and what should you do if you get it? We spoke to a few experts to find out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Dishes for the Weary Diner
description: In New York City, it’s easy to take great meals for granted. These three restaurants know how to delight and surprise.
content: Without fail, the first thing I notice when I’m not in New York or other major cities is how difficult it can be to find a fantastic, write-home-about-it meal. This isn’t a knock on suburbs — which are in the midst of their own dining revolution — but rather an acknowledgment: Finding a great meal in New York can be as effortless as breathing. And it can be easy to take that access for granted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Serena Williams Says She Will Retire From Tennis Sometime After U.S. Open
description: In a cover story for Vogue, Williams said she was “evolving away from tennis, toward other things that are important to me.”
content: The world first came to know Serena Williams as a 17-year-old with beaded braids, overwhelming power and precocious intelligence and poise when she stunned her sport by winning the first of her 23 Grand Slam singles titles at the 1999 U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About ‘Bad Sex’ but Were Afraid to Ask
description: In a quest to explore her own sexuality, Nona Willis Aronowitz hit the sheets — and the books.
content: “Bad sex” has become a catchphrase in recent years, shorthand for the ways that sex can still be unequal and sometimes not-quite-consensual. When I picked up “Bad Sex,” Nona Willis Aronowitz’s new book, I was prepared for an analysis of sexual politics post-#MeToo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Explosions Rip Through Russian Base on Crimea
description: A senior Ukrainian official said his country’s forces were responsible, which Ukraine did not publicly confirm or deny. Russian officials said only that munitions had detonated.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — A series of explosions rocked a key Russian air base in Kremlin-occupied Crimea on Tuesday, killing at least one person and sowing confusion among local officials about the cause and whether Ukraine’s military could threaten targets on the peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: Snapchat Introduces Its First Parental Controls
description: The messaging app, which is popular with teenagers, has faced legal pressure to roll out tools so parents can keep an eye on their children’s social media activity.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Snapchat, the ephemeral messaging app, introduced its first parental controls on Tuesday, as social media platforms face increasing scrutiny for exposing young users to potentially harmful content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson
title: On Republican turf, a Minnesota Democrat is highlighting his stance on abortion rights.
description: The Democrat Jeff Ettinger, running in a special election for a House seat in southern Minnesota, is in favor of passing legislation that would codify Roe v. Wade into federal law.
content: A week after voters in deep-red Kansas lined up behind abortion rights, a Minnesota Democrat is hoping his special election on Tuesday offers evidence that his party can use the issue to its advantage — even in Republican areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Songwriter and His Sister Take on a Hollywood Hills Fixer-Upper
description: When your sibling is a real estate agent and an interior designer, why would you work with anyone else?
content: CJ Baran needed a new home in Los Angeles for personal and professional reasons. After living in an apartment for years, Mr. Baran, 32, a songwriter and music producer, longed for a house with a view and outdoor space. But he was also desperately in need of a home where he could make some noise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 12 Recap: Hit the Road
description: Kim would like to make a confession, Gene has a new problem, and Jeff has car trouble.
content: After years of blending in and keeping low in Omaha, Gene Takavic, a.k.a. Saul Goodman, is about to lam it. In the closing moments of this episode, he is outed for good by a terrified but determined Marion, who has discovered the truth about her overly helpful pal. All it took was a computer, Ask Jeeves and a few key words: “Con man” and “Albuquerque.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: What’s Next for This New York Theater Leader? Nursing School
description: The artistic director of Rattlestick Playwrights Theater is making an unusual career change after preparing the company for a major renovation.
content: There’s been a lot of turnover in theater leadership lately. Some have been drummed out of their jobs. Others have quit to do something else in the arts. Many have retired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Serena Williams Leaves Tennis Just as She Played: On Her Own Terms
description: Williams brought her own distinctive flair to tennis, challenging norms that governed fashion, power, decorum, race and gender. By being herself, Williams’s reach far exceeded the game.
content: She is a symbol. A persona. An athlete who has gone far beyond the footsteps of her trailblazing sister and came to rule a cloistered, mostly white sport. She refuses to stop there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Chipotle Agrees to Pay Over $20 Million to Settle New York City Workplace Case
description: The city contended that the fast-food chain violated scheduling and sick-leave laws for more than four years, affecting 13,000 employees.
content: New York City said Tuesday that it had reached a settlement potentially worth more than $20 million with the fast-food chain Chipotle Mexican Grill over violations of worker protection laws, the largest settlement of its kind in the city’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Three Sentences That Could Change the World — and Your Life
description: The philosopher William MacAskill lays out the case for longtermism: “Future people count. There could be a lot of them. And we can make their lives better.”
content: Today’s show is built around three simple sentences: “Future people count. There could be a lot of them. And we can make their lives better.” Those sentences form the foundation of an ethical framework known as “longtermism.” They might sound obvious, but to take them seriously is a truly radical endeavor — one with the power to change the world and even your life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett
title: Republican governors criticize the Mar-a-Lago search as ‘unprecedented’ and ‘un-American.’
description: Several Trump allies echoed the former president’s claims that the Justice Department was being used as a weapon against Trump.
content: The F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home in Florida drew swift condemnation on Monday evening from some Republican governors who quickly backed Mr. Trump’s message that the Justice Department was being used against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Republicans Rally Behind Trump, Who Reprises Favored Role: Victim
description: Arguments used against Hillary Clinton in the 2016 email inquiry are long forgotten as G.O.P. officials rush to condemn the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans sought Tuesday to turn the F.B.I.’s search of Donald J. Trump’s Florida home into a rallying point, positioning the former president in his political comfort zone as a partisan target and victim, while effectively suspending the party’s efforts to focus on other issues heading into the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Neelam Bohra, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Ava Sasani
title: Albuquerque Police Detain Suspect in Killings of Muslim Men
description: The shootings of four Muslim men since November may be connected, the police have said, raising fears in a place where many immigrants and refugees had felt at home.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — For days, the news that someone might be killing Muslim men in Albuquerque spread fear among the city’s Muslim residents, some of whom were so afraid of becoming the next target that they fled town or hunkered down in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Crazy Eddie’s Life Was Insane!
description: In “Retail Gangster,” Gary Weiss explores the life and sketchy business practices of Eddie Antar, whose commercials are the stuff of legend.
content: The most famous TV ad in the Orwellian year of 1984, carefully themed to the novel named for this year, was for the Apple Macintosh desktop computer. The most infamous were those for Crazy Eddie, a chain of discount electronics stores in the New York metropolitan area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tochi Onyebuchi
title: In This Novel, Witchcraft Makes Women Powerful, and Vulnerable
description: In “The Women Could Fly,” women are uniquely capable of magic, which leads the government to strictly monitor and regulate them.
content: In the world of “The Women Could Fly,” Megan Giddings’s second novel, the government mandates that women marry by age 30; by age 28, unmarried women must enroll in a registry. Those who resist should gear up for a future post-carceral in its complexion. The justification? Women are uniquely capable of witchcraft. What in another world might be called miracles are, here, baleful strangenesses. More quotidian phenomena are attributed to women and witchcraft too. If you’ve come down with a fever that won’t go away, a witch did it. If your husband cheats on you, a witch made him do it. “Witch” is an epithet, and witches are still burned at the stake, women a danger to be corralled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Demand for Italian Beef Is Booming. Thank ‘The Bear.’
description: The FX series has fueled a spike in sales of the sandwich at Chicago-specialty restaurants across the country.
content: Last month, Dan Michaels, an owner of Gino’s East of Chicago in Los Angeles, watched as orders for Italian beef — the classic Chicago sandwich of thinly sliced roast beef and tangy giardiniera piled on a roll — suddenly soared to 300 a day, from 150 a day in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: New Laws of the Land: Sierra Leone Reshapes Environmental Battleground
description: The West African nation will let communities veto mining, farming and industrial projects. Activists say the legislation is a progressive landmark. At least one investor calls it unworkable.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — It is a struggle that communities across the world have faced: stopping companies from grabbing their lands, polluting their environment and forcing them to relocate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Brooks Barnes
title: Walmart Ponders Streaming Deal With Paramount, Disney and Comcast
description: The retail giant is exploring bundling a streaming service into its Walmart+ membership program.
content: Walmart has held discussions with major media companies about including streaming entertainment in its membership service, according to three people with knowledge of the conversations, part of an effort to extend its relationship with customers beyond its brick-and-mortar stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 7: On ‘Is the World Really Falling Apart, or Does It Just Feel That Way?’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Ivy Qin, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We received 1,315 entries from students from around the world for the seventh week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Ivy Qin, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Prosecutions of ex-leaders elsewhere show benefits, but also risks.
description: Prosecutions against former heads of state are exceedingly rare in the United States, heightening public shock at the latest development in the escalating federal investigations into former President Donald J. Trump.

title: The Timeline Leading Up to the F.B.I.’s Search of Mar-a-Lago
description: Investigators and the National Archives have spent months seeking information about what materials are stored at former President Donald J. Trump’s home.
content: When F.B.I. agents took the stunning step of searching former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida on Monday, the focus quickly turned to Mr. Trump’s history of improperly keeping records and documents from his time in the White House at his Florida residence.

title: In Italy, Where Pizza Was Born, Domino’s Bows Out
description: The company entered the Italian market in 2015, but seems to have been done in by a proliferation of home-delivery food during the pandemic and a desire for more artisanal pies.
content: ROME — It turns out that Italians don’t necessarily like pineapple on their pizza, after all. Or at least not enough to keep nearly three dozen Domino’s Pizza franchises afloat.
